fields.description:
* A repository setup with default reviewers
 * Destination branch permissions set with merge checks 
 ** Check for at least # approval from default reviewers
 ** Check for unresolved pull request tasks
 ** Prevent a merge with unresolved merge checks (Premium feature)
 * The features will prevent a default reviewer from merging a pull request they created unless another default reviewer approves the pull request. 

Add an option for default reviewers to merge their own pull requests without needing approval from another default reviewer.
fields.summary: Allow default reviewers to merge a pull request they create

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Environment-dashboard and deployments history are very slow and sometimes times out.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
1. Click on deployments
2. Click on the environment name, in the green section
3. A window should open, with the Environment History. 

h3. Expected Results
The environment history will show the results of the query in a timely manner

h3. Actual Results
It will intermittently, either keep spinning forever or eventually load the history.

h3. Workaround
 Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: environment-dashboard and deployments history are very slow

fields.description:
This feature request is to add the ability to add exceptions for the "Require issue keys in commit messages" feature, like a whitelist to allow users to bypass this requirement.

This would be important for users such as bot accounts that would push back to Bitbucket.
fields.summary: Add exceptions for the "Require issue keys in commit messages" feature
Support for "git clone --filter" needed

fields.description: It would be nice if we could have a repository setting that allows us to specify a certain set of default tasks that get added to every pull request.
fields.summary: Default Tasks for Pull Requests

fields.description:
We have a standard git-flow for our projects, mainly triggering pipeline by branch. Some projects are hosted on AWS, others not. The deployment steps for AWS and a VPS that accepts a git push require different images and scripts to run. Some projects mix and match between AWS and VPS for the different environments.

It would be helpful to have all the deployment steps in one config file and be able to choose which are triggered based on a combination of the git branch and BB repository variables.
fields.summary: Trigger pipeline step conditionally based on environment variables

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Repository variables with the same name as the custom variables can be used as a default if custom variables are kept blank during pipeline kickoff.

{color:#ff8b00}*Issue:*{color} The above only works when the pipeline is triggered from the pipelines tab:
 !Screen Shot 2020-01-29 at 17.35.34.png|width=581,height=72!

And, not when triggering pipeline from 'Branches' page and 'Commit' page.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Configure Pipelines as below:
 !Screen Shot 2020-01-29 at 17.12.55.png|width=616,height=233!
 # Trigger pipeline from the pipelines tab keeping the custom variable field empty and output prints the value defined in the repository variables. It can be used as a workaround for the users who wants to have some default value for custom variables.
 # However, it fails to print the repository variables when:
 ## The pipeline is triggered from the Branches page keeping the custom variable field empty.
 ## The pipeline is triggered from the commit page keeping the custom variable field empty.

h3. Expected Results

The custom pipeline run from the pipelines tab, branches page and commit page should show similar behavior.
h3. Actual Results

The expected behavior is only met when the pipeline is triggered through the pipelines tab. And not from branches, commit page.
h3. Workaround

Running custom pipelines from the pipelines tab.
fields.summary: Inconsistent behaviour when triggering custom pipelines with blank/undefined variables

fields.description:
Summary:
 To remove the notification "*revoked your access to the repository*" when a group or a user is removed from repository access.

Use case for this being:
For an atlassian site administrator if a colleague asks me to add permission to a particular bitbucket repository but when I add a permission I make an error and add another user permission. Then I fix the error and put the correct user permission. In the meanwhile the other user is notified that I have revoked his permission.
fields.summary: Allow Admins to not notify users when access is revoked

fields.description:
As an user, I would like to be able to search a specific file in all repository branches using global repository search.

Steps to reproduce:
Open the repository in question
Use the magnifier at the top left of the screen
Search for the file

Currently behavior:
it only displays files within the default (usually master) branch.

Expected behavior:
The search to display files and directories/branches these files are located

As a workaround, we have to use the search feature located within Source tab and we have to manually search each branch which is a pain.
fields.summary: Improve repository code search

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

If you have a binary file and you want to view commit history for that file on Bitbucket UI via the Commit History dropdown button, it doesn't show anything, it just keeps loading.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Upload a binary file into your repository
 # Open the file on Bitbucket UI
 # Click the *Commit History* drop-down button (Before the *Full commit* button)
 # You'll notice that it loads indefinitely (See attached screenshot)

h3. Expected Results

Past commits for the binary file should show in the commit history dropdown
h3. Actual Results

The commit history just loads indefinitely

h3. Workaround
* Select the specific commit that you want to download the file by visiting Commits option on the left side in the repository
* Select the file, click on view file and select Open Raw for the menu option on the upper right (three horizontal dots)
fields.summary: Clicking the commit history dropdown button on Bitbucket UI doesn't load for binary files

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Add repositories to a project of a team screen is showing an error
{code:java}
Request parameter repo_ids must not be empty {code}
Originally raised as [Community question|https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Bitbucket-questions/Error-importing-repositories-from-local-account-Request/qaq-p/1278704].
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to [https://bitbucket.org/account/user/]<team>/projects/<project_key>
 # Click on Add repositories button in the top right corner
 # Select repositories to add
 # Click Add repositories

Same issue happens when adding repositories from an individual account after the Transfer ownership of repositories dialog is shown.
h3. Expected Results

Repository moved/transferred to the team's project.
h3. Actual Results

Not very useful error shown in the UI. Repositories left intact.
h3. Workaround

Move/transfer each repository via its settings. No bulk move/transfer workaround.
fields.summary: Error when importing repositories to a team project

fields.description:
Currently when a repository has a large number of Refs (Tags/Branches) we see significant degradation in UI performance, with frequent time outs during platform peak hours. 

Currently Bitbucket supports around 1500 refs without experiencing degraded performance. Any repository that has more than that, will see performance degradation. 

 

Please help improve performance and support a large number of REFs on repository to improve customer experience.
fields.summary: Improve performance for PRs and loading of commits page when repo has large number of REFs

fields.description:
For debugging purposes, this feature request is to highlight the commands run on .sh scripts as if they were added on the bitbucket-pipelines.yml file.

This will make troubleshooting commands that are inside .sh files much easier, as it would show clearly which command has failed from the script.
fields.summary: Show commands run from .sh scripts in Pipelines

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When typing a long inline comment, auto-scrolling stops making you type offscreen. 
Also, the left grey bar do not scrolls, taking up some horizontal space.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a new inline comment on new PR screen
 # Type a longe comment making the textbox scroll

h3. Expected Results
Textbox scroll as you type

h3. Actual Results
Do not scroll, making you type offscreen

h3. Workaround
No workaround
fields.summary: Typing inline comments do not scroll, making you type offscreen

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When a user is invited to a public pull request he/she will have read access and would be capable of approving it and watching/unwatching the same. In situations where the pull request remains open this will will show-up on the users pull request back-log when he logs in.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Step 1: Create a Public Repository
 # Step 2: Now, create a Pull Request and invite a user as a reviewer. Note, he/she should not be a part of the repository/team earlier
 # Step 3: Now, after the user approves the pull request. Try to come out of the repository or lose the pull request

h3. Expected Results

Needs to have a way to come out of the pull request or close the same
h3. Actual Results

Users cannot come out of the pull request once they approve it and don't have an option to opt out of the repository. 

 The below exception is thrown in the xxxxxxx.log file:
{noformat}
None{noformat}
h3. Workaround

Needs to contact the user to ask him to merge and close the pull request.
fields.summary: Users invited to public repo pull request cannot opt out of PR/Repository

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Admins are not being notified as expected when transferring repositories from one workspace to another where they are an admin of both.

This happens in 3 different scenarios...
 # Repository transferred from a TEAM workspace, to an Individual workspace - none of the admins of the target workspace are being notified, regardless of if there are 1 or more admins on the target workspace
 # Repository transferred from Individual workspace to TEAM workspace with multiple admins - The admin who initiated the transfer does not get the email to accept the transfer, but the other admins will get the email. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
h4. Scenario 1 - Transfer repository from Team workspace to Individual Workspace
 # Create a repository on a team workspace where you are an admin
 # Transfer the repository to an individual workspace where you are an admin
 # Observe that the admin(s) of individual workspace do not receive repository transfer request email

h4. Scenario 2 - Transfer repository from Individual workspace to TEAM workspace with multiple admins
Transfer repository from Individual workspace to TEAM workspace with multiple admins

# Create a Team workspace with multiple admins including yourself
# Create a repository on an individual workspace where you are an admin
# Transfer that repository to the Team workspace with multiple admins
# You will not receive a notification but the other admins will. 

h4. Scenario 3 - Transfer repository from TEAM workspace A to TEAM workspace B where the user is an admin on both workspaces

# Create a shared workspace A
# Create a shared workspace B
# Make sure you are the only admin on both worksapces
# Transfer repo  from A to B -> You will not receive n email
# Add another admin on Workspace B (lets call him user X)
# Transfer repo from A to B -> You will not get an email but user X will.

h3. Expected Results

A transfer notification would be sent to all administrators in the workspace receiving the transfer request. (Redirect link if you are the admin on both workspaces) and email for the other admins. 
h3. Actual Results

The administrator who triggered the transfer request does not get the transfer notification email nor does he get a redirect link. 
h3. Workaround

Workaround
For Scenario 1, The source workspace needs to have multiple admins. Then, Another admin of the shared workspace (if present) has to raise the transfer request. This way, the admin of the individual workspace will get a notification.
For Scenario 2, The target workspace needs to have multiple admins, then the other admins will receive a notification.
fields.summary: Transferring a repo between workspaces you have admin access does not get a transfer notification sent to the transfer requestor

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Adding {{-merge}} to .gitattributes file prevents the file to show on changed files list on the pull request UI if the file contains merge conflicts.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # add a .gitattributes file with "test.c -merge" statement
 # perform conflicting commits between two branches
 # create a pull request from these branches

h3. Expected Results
 # file "test.c" should have the diff showing and should be listed on the changed files list on the right bar

h3. Actual Results

No diffs are shown for the file and file is not listed on the right bar
h3. Workaround

No workaround

Comment from the internal development team:
{panel}
This does not allow users to sneak changes through a pull request, as we will still prevent the pull request from merging until the conflicts are resolved, at which point the changes will be visible again.
{panel}
fields.summary: Adding -merge to .gitattributes prevents the file showing diffs or appearing in changed files on a pull request

fields.description:
In PR page, commits list, I'd like to see the status icon of each commit (approved, comments quantity or nothing).

Thanks in advance.

Marcio
fields.summary: Commit status icon in PR page

fields.description: This feature request is to add the ability to backup metadata such as pull requests and Pipelines build history so that it's possible to restore a repository completely if needed.
fields.summary: Add the ability to backup metadata

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Currently, when a user creates a pull request with empty fork repositories we only give them an error message code, this could be handled better by informing the user that their fork has empty commit. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create empty repositories
 # Fork the repositories
 # Create a PR to the fork
fields.summary: Creating pull request from empty fork repositories will only give error code

fields.description:
This is a feature request for BB Pipelines.

My multi-region service has multiple production environments, let's call them prod-east and prod-west. There is a manual gate to deploy to production.

What the team would like to do is:
 * To be able to trigger a "fire and forget" deployment to both production regions. Ideally the regions would be deployed in parallel (currently not possible due to BCLOUD-16650), although it would be OK to do it sequentially, provided that the operator does not have to wait for one region to finish its deployment before they can trigger the second region.
 * To be able to deploy individually to the regions independently and in any sequence. At the moment, the deployments can only occur in the sequence described in the Yaml file. If the Yaml file contains the East,West sequence, then it is not possible for an operator to deploy first to West.

Bamboo Deployments offers the flexibility do accomplish these goals. The operator can independently trigger deployments to each region, in any order. The operator can also trigger the deployments to both regions without having to wait for a region to finish in order to press the button to deploy to the other region. It would be great to have the same flexibility in BB Pipelines.
fields.summary: Flexibility to manually deploy to multiple environments in any sequence

fields.description:
Pipelines currently supports providing names of variables that are provided values when run manually for custom pipelines.

Another use case for custom pipelines is running them on a schedule.

We could allow setting a default value to provide a value for the custom pipeline (as described here: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BCLOUD-18771) on a schedule but if you use the same custom pipeline with two values it would require two different pipelines each with the same config but different default value.

Instead we could extend the schedule pipeline config to allow providing a value for the custom variables that we provide to the pipeline each time we run it on a schedule.
fields.summary: Support providing values for custom variables on scheduled pipelines.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
 * On the pull request dashboard page filter by team. Refresh the page the column headers become distorted and it looks like there should be sorting filers but they're unusable

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Navigate to the Bitbucket dashboard (Click the Bibucet icon on the top left)
 # Click on 'Pull requests' on the navigation panel
 # Select 'Teams' as the "Filter by:" option
 # Refresh the page

h3. Expected Results
 * No header distortions and if sort filters are available they should useable

h3. Actual Results
 * Headers distorted and sort filters are not usable

h3. Workaround

Navigate away from the page and go back to the page.
fields.summary: Refreshing the pull request dashboard page when the team filer is used causes issues with the column headers

fields.description:
When creating a deployment environment in Bitbucket Cloud under Repository settings > Deployments, it's possible that a very similar environment to the one you are creating exists, with dozens of variables in it.
It takes a long time to recreate a deployment environment, while the environment has already been created once.

The request here would be to add a button to "clone" existing deployment environments, which would copy all deployment variables from the copied environment to a newly created clone.
fields.summary: Duplicate a deployment environment

fields.description:
Please split the Team permission "Administer team" into two distinct security groups. 

We have a need to have different members be responsible for each of these functions, and we can't configure it as all our Admins have too much of some kind of power. 

Preference:
 * One group to update team settings
 * One group to administer repositories

General security practice is to split groups anytime the word "and" appears in the description, as it demonstrates the split purposes of the role.

 

Thanks!

Jason
fields.summary: Split "Administer team" Team Permission into two settings

fields.description:
At this time, pipe variables can only be defined within the pipe block, for example:
{code:java}
- pipe: atlassian/aws-code-deploy:0.3.2
              variables:
                AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID: '<string>'
                AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY: '<string>'
                AWS_DEFAULT_REGION: '<string>'
                APPLICATION_NAME: '<string>'
                COMMAND: '<string>' 
{code}
This becomes a redundant approach if more one pipes are used as part of different steps using the same credentials.

Having a common way to define pipe variables would make a better alternative for configurations having multiple pipes configured.
fields.summary: Common way to define pipes variables if more than one pipe is used.

fields.description:
Currently Bitbucket only allows branching model to be configured per repository. It's very unlikely that company's or person's branching model preferences would change with every repository.

Current model forces me remember to set branching model every time a new repository is created. It would save a lot of time and trouble if I can configure this at account level and every repository I create would default to this model (with an option to override).
fields.summary: Allow default branching model configuration for account

fields.description:
When reading comments or replies to inline comments in pull request UI, texts are cropped to the right. 

In those cases, the reader needs to scroll the texts left and right in order to read everything.

This happens on MAC display with resolution 1440 x 900. Does not happen using 1920x1080 display.
Hiding the right column also does not shows the comments and replies completely

*Workaround*
Zoom out browser to 90%.
fields.summary: Inline comments in PR should be rendered to fit screen - no need to scroll

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Gmail has a feature of grouping emails based on subject or email header, as per:
 * [https://support.google.com/mail/answer/5900?co=GENIE.Platform%3DDesktop&hl=en]

As a result, Bitbucket email notifications on e.g. a certain Pull Request, get grouped for users who have a Gmail account.

However, email notifications on failed builds include the commit hash in their subject: as a result, emails about failed builds on a certain branch are not grouped together, since they don't have the same subject.

It is also not possible for users to disable Pipelines email notifications for failed builds that are triggered by them (see here:https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BCLOUD-19809)

As a result, a user may end up having a lot of email notifications on Pipelines failed builds, which cannot be disabled and are also not grouped together.
h3. Suggested Solution

Users that use a Gmail email in their Bitbucket account, have asked that the commit hash is removed from the subject of emails on failed Pipelines builds, so that the emails can be grouped together in their GMail Inbox
fields.summary: Remove commit hash from the subject of email notifications on failed Pipelines builds

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Specifically, when using 'docker caching' in Pipelines the time taken to compress and upload cache is not being added to the "Build teardown" step. Therefore, the total time accrued during the build with docker caching involved would show a different total build time when compared to the sum of the time taken for each individual step.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
* Run a pipelines build with docker caching enabled
* Pull a heavy image during the build.
* The docker cache compress and upload time in Build Teardown step will not be involved. Thus the total build time will be different when compared to the time taken by each individual step.

h3. Expected Results
* The Build Teardown step in pipelines build should include the time taken by docker cache compression and upload.

h3. Actual Results

* The time taken by docker caching compression and upload is not included within build teardown step. However, this is not the case with custom caching and the issue is just restricted to docker caching.

(on) That being said, all features and billing seem to be in order and the total time taken for the build is correct.

h3. Workaround

The only workaround here is to reach out to support to know about the actual time taken for the build teardown step if docker caching is involved.
fields.summary: Pipelines build teardown step doesn't record the duration it takes to compress and upload the docker cache

fields.description:
Currently there is the feature to remove PR approvals when the source branch changes. We love that to make sure there aren't big changes after the approvals that then get merged in without actually being reviewed. This feature is starting to be more of a hinderance when people are just trying to sync up their feature branches or resolve conflicts.

This feature would change the default behavior or add a new option which removes the approvals when the code diff changes, or perhaps with a percentage change limit. This fixes an inconvenience where the PR gets approvals, then the branch is synced with the target and the reviewers have to look through the code again when there isn't actually anything new to review.
fields.summary: Remove PR approvals only when the diff changes

fields.description: In [https://bitbucket.org/dashboard/pullrequests] when I click in a project name it would be nice to redirect to the pull-request's page of that project.
fields.summary: Improvement in PR dashboard
Pipelines filter out Docker syscall policy

fields.description:
Backup Bitbucket Team profile(s) with settings/member definitions/projects/repo settings/pipelines or even git repos.

Similar to Google Download  [https://support.google.com/accounts/answer/3024190?hl=en] 

Also be able to import settings and data back to Bitbucket.

 

[https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Bitbucket-questions/Backup-Bitbucket-profile-and-GIT/qaq-p/1272941]
fields.summary: BCloud Backup/restore GIT Repos with settings

fields.description:
It would be really nice to allow users to star PRs (at least the ones that get merged). That would allow users to quickly search for really important/relevant things that all the developers in a team should be aware of (important bugs, relevant implementations, refactors, etc).

People who are in change of merging code could star PRs that all developers should know about but in turn users should also be able to star PRs that they find important for themselves (these would only be visible on a per account basis).
fields.summary: Allow users to "star" (or badge) pull requests

fields.description: I frequently go into editing mode when trying to select/copy the description of an item. It would be better to default to read only mode and add an edit button to enable changing the description of an item.
fields.summary: Default to read-only mode and Add a button for editing

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Dear Atlassian,

I find the behavior of the PR overview diff objectionable.

The diff that is shown on the overview page of a PR seems to be generated on the fly against the latest master branch of the project and I would to argue that this is not the right thing to do.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Step 1 : Have a Git repository with some files on Bitbucket cloud.
 # Step 2 : Clone the repository locally.
 # Step 3 : Create a local branch
 # Step 4 : Modify a file.
 # Step 5 : Commit this file.
 # Step 6 : Push your branch to Bitbucket.
 # Step 7 : Create a PR off the branch.
 # Step 8 : Locally create a new branch from the master.
 # Step 9 : Modify the same file from step (4) in a conflicting way.
 # Step 10 : Commit your changes locally.
 # Step 11 : Push the new branch.
 # Step 12 : Create a PR off the new branch.
 # Step 13 : Merge the PR.
 # Step 14 : Navigate to the overview page of the PR from step (7).

h3. Expected Results

The diff shown is unchanged, i.e. you see the same diff as the one you were seeing after step (7).
h3. Actual Results

The diff now shows the conflicts that have been caused by the PR from step (12).

The below exception is thrown in the xxxxxxx.log file:
{noformat}
...NA..
{noformat}
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available

The described behavior impedes the review process, because now, instead of seeing the original diff, reviewers see the diff against the latest master branch and there are conflicts in this diff that make reviewing hard/impossible.

Competing products (Github's PR's and ReviewBoard's review requests are two such products that I have some experience with) always show the diff against the commit that was used to create the PR branch.

Of course when there are conflicts you are required to resolve them before merging your change, but the point is that you shouldn't need to resolve them the moment these conflicts occur, i.e. the review process should not be affected by conflict resolution.
fields.summary: PR overview diff is counterproductive

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
The close source branch checkbox on merge is disabled on two different sessions.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
1. Start an incognito chrome browser
2. Login and navigate to repository pull requests
3. Create a pull request with close branch checked
4. choose merge and notice close branch is checked
5. close the browser
6. Start an incognito chrome browser
7. Login and navigate to repository pull requests
8. Select your newly created pull request
9. choose merge and notice close branch is not selected and cannot be
selected

h3. Expected Results
The close source branch checkbox is selected and not disabled.

h3. Actual Results
The close source branch checkbox is disabled.

h3. Workaround
Hard refresh the PR page should make the close source branch checkbox work as expected again.
fields.summary: close source branch checkbox on merge dialog incorrectly disabled

fields.description: At this time, the deployment tab on repositories has cards displayed for each successful deployment with just a commit hash. Some additional information like the branch it belongs to would make it a better feature and saves the user two additional step of clicking the deployment environment card and then clicking the commit hash to check the associated branch on the commit page.
fields.summary: Add build metadata to Deployments dashboard (e.g. branch)
Create comments in Pull requests via the API in the past

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
According to our API documentation, it's expected that the "State" parameter supports the following values:
MERGED
SUPERSEDED
OPEN
DECLINED

Source:
https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/repositories/%7Bworkspace%7D/%7

When attempting to parse this value through a valid JSON though, the status will always be "OPEN", no matter what's on the JSON.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
Run an API call like this to create a PR on a repository:
 curl https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/<user>/<repo>/pullrequests \
    -u <usrn>:<passwd> \
    --request POST \
    --header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    --data '{
        "title": "My Title",
        "source": {
            "branch": {
                "name": "MyBranch"
            },
            "state":"MERGED"
        }
    }'

h3. Expected Results
The pull request is created with the status being specified in the JSON.

h3. Actual Results
The pull request is being created with the "Open" status, regardless of what's on the JSON.

h3. Workaround
 Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Creating a pull request through the API does not allow for different statuses

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Assume a user that is NOT watching a repository in Bitbucket, or they are watching it, but they are NOT subscribed to notifications for Pipelines.

If this user pushes a commit or opens a PR that triggers a Pipelines build and this build fails, the user will STILL receive an email notification for it.

This can be confusing for users, since they have unsubscribed for Pipelines notifications in the repo and still receive those emails, and there is no way to turn them off.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Stop watching a repository you have access to from the repo's *Source* page >> *...* > *Manage notifications*
 ** Alternatively, do not stop watching the repo, but only unsubscribe from Pipelines notifications for this repo
 # Configure a bitbucket-pipelines.yml file so you can run Pipelines builds on the repo. Include an invalid command in your script, so that the build fails.
 # Push a commit to the repo that will trigger above pipeline.

h3. Expected Results

The build fails and the user does NOT receive an email notification about it, since they have unsubscribed from Pipelines notifications.
h3. Actual Results

The build fails, and the user STILL receives an email notification about it, even though they have unsubscribed from Pipelines notifications.
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior.
fields.summary: Users who push a commit or open a PR that triggers a Pipelines build, still receive an email notification if this build fails, even if they are NOT watching the repository

fields.description:
A Webhooks event is getting triggered, when the title of the PR is changed and the "pullrequests:updated" field is ticked in the Webhooks' settings.

It would be a useful feature if:
- Enabling the "pullrequests:updated" webhooks would not triggered a Webhooks event, once the PR's title is changed 
OR
- Create a separate Webhooks event for PR, which triggers a webhooks event once the PR's title is changed.
fields.summary: Webhooks is triggered when the PR's title is changed

fields.description:
This use case is meant to apply when using a fork and branch strategy. As a developer, I create a fork of the primary repo, then create a branch so that I can make updates. Once my changes are made, I create a PR that targets a branch (ie master) in the primary repo, and add multiple reviewers. While those reviewers do have access to the primary repo, they not have access to my private fork.

What I'm proposing is to allow the PR author the ability to grant editor access to a PR, which would automatically allow the editors read/write access to the branch in the fork, but then remove that access once the PR has been merged. This would also not count towards the 5 user limit of the private fork. In order to do this today, you have to explicitly grant a user read/write access to the repo and then remove that access once the PR is merged. This work flow is a bit clunky and due to the 5 user limit, limits the number of "editors". Also, this helps minimize how long a PR is left open with unresolved tasks if the author is no longer available to update the PR.
fields.summary: Allow multiple editors on a pull request across forks

fields.description:
Hello bitbucket-team,

is it somehow possible to cache a custom build image? 

Every build and step runs inside a custom Docker image, and will pull my custom Docker image first. The image is quite large and it takes a while to pull.

It would be great if I could cache the image after the first pull that it doesn´t waste so much time in following steps.

The only solution I know so far is to reduce all steps to one step. But this isn´t a good solution for me as steps are making my pipeline more structured. 

Thanks,
Fabian
fields.summary: Caching custom pipeline image

fields.description: When listing repositories on Bitbucket it would be nice to have the description of each project too. Showing only the name is often now enough information.
fields.summary: Show repository descritions in repository list

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Bitbucket Pipelines is unable to cache Docker image which have "scratch" image as one of the layer

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create the following Dockerfile
{code}
FROM ubuntu:18.04 as base
FROM scratch
ENV foo /bar
{code}
 # Run the following steps in Pipelines:
{code}
docker build -t scratchtest .
docker save scratchtest -o scratchtest.tar 
{code}

h3. Expected Results
Command runs successfully
h3. Actual Results
Error response from daemon: empty export - not implemented

h3. Workaround

Use --cache-from feature of Docker. With this feature a previous built image can be used to build the new image. In this process all the layers which have not been changed will be used from the cache image  
* https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/build/
* https://andrewlock.net/caching-docker-layers-on-serverless-build-hosts-with-multi-stage-builds---target,-and---cache-from/
fields.summary: Bitbucket Pipelines is unable to cache Docker image which have "scratch" image

fields.description:
This is a feature request for BB Pipelines/Deployments.

At the moment, deployment notifications can only be configured for all repo, or per branch.

My team always deploys from master, so per-branch configuration is not very valuable. Also, we deploy continuously to non-production environments, so we have lots of deployments there. At the moment we face a dilemma:
 * If we enable deployment notifications, then we are spammed due to our frequent deployments to non-production environments.
 * If we do not enable deployment notifications, then we are not notified when a new release is deployed to production.

In order to allow teams to optimise the signal/noise ratio of their deployment notifications, could you please make them configurable per-environment?
fields.summary: Per-environment control of deployment notifications

fields.description:
This is a suggestion for a design change in BB Deployments, in particular in the "Deployments" tab (/addon/pipelines/deployments).

Currently in BB Deployments the "Promote" button to trigger a manual promotion is located inside the *source environment*, the one that contains the release to be promoted. This makes sense, but it is confusing for the folks coming from Bamboo. In Bamboo, the process to promote a release is the inverse: you first go to the *target environment* (where you want to promote the release to), and then select the release to be promoted.

One idea would be to move the promote button to in-between the environments. This would increase its discoverability and make it obvious how the releases flow.
fields.summary: Relocate 'Promote' button in BB Deployments to improve discoverability

fields.description:
Trello should display Card#  when user adds a new card to list to report a bug or an issue. When user clicks a card it gets opened and one can watch in Action>Share button as shown in attached images

!image-2020-01-16-15-42-06-273.png!
fields.summary: Trello should display Card#  as displayed in ACTIONS>SHARE

fields.description:
Hello,

When using my screen reader, I used to look for the "+" or "-" symbols at the beginning of changed or unchanged lines. E.g. "-" meant the line was being changed in some way, and "+" meant the line to take the previous changed lines place. Could you please add these back to the new pull request experience?

Thanks.
fields.summary: Add + and - back to diffs for screen reader users

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
If for any reason the tests print any output, the logs are not sanitized and are showing the content even for secured variables

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Any test report run that prints secured variable value


h3. Expected Results
Values are masked by secured variables

h3. Actual Results
Values are not masked 

h3. Workaround
Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Print tests output on pipelines doesn't mask secured variables

fields.description:
Currently, checking the diff in a file, Bitbucket only displays the last 9 commits in the dropdown.

It would be good to either increase this number or add a "load more" button at the bottom of the dropdown.

(i) Currently, as a workaround, it is necessary to change the URL commits ref, in order to proceed with the file diff.

eg.

https://bitbucket.org/<owner>/<repository>/diff/<filepath/filename>?at=<target_branch>&diff1=<commit_hash>&diff2=<commit_hash>
fields.summary: File diff only shows the last 9 commits

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

There are some specific cases in Bitbucket Cloud Online Editor, when a file is edited, a BOM (<U+FEFF>) character is added in the file, which results a non-successful build in Pipelines
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Push an XML file generated by Visual Studio to Bitbucket using Team Explorer
 # Create a pull request manually from Bitbucket with this new file in the commit list
 # Edit the XML file
 # After modifying the XML file, a BOM character will be added into the first line

h3. Expected Results

When editing a file no extra BOM character is added
h3. Actual Results

A BOM character is added
h3. Workaround

The issue happens for those files that were saved with an encoding option that stores BOM character(Eg: _*Save with Encoding->UTF-8 with BOM)*_ and then pushed to Bitbucket. When editing these files in Bitbucket UI, we see a red dot(BOM character) at the beginning of the file. If you hover the dot you'll see it's likely \ufeff.

As a workaround, when saving the file in your local system you can use an encoding option that doesn't store BOM (like _*Save with Encoding->UTF-8*_ option) and then commit the file to Bitbucket. You will not see red dot(BOM character) while editing the new file in UI as it doesn't have a BOM character.
fields.summary: Editing a file in Online Editor may add a BOM (<U+FEFF>) character

fields.description:
Currently, in Bitbucket Cloud the changes in branch permissions are not recorded in the Audit log.

It would be helpful if we add the changes in branch permissions in the Audit log similar to the Server edition of BitBucket.
fields.summary: Add the changes in branch permissions in the Audit log

fields.description:
On the repository page -> top/right -> next to CLONE button ->  ...  button.

Clicking shows panel and among others 'Leave repository.'

'Leave repository' suggest a clean leaving the page, like logout from your bank visit oss, not removing further access to the repository.

Indeed I lost access this way to the repository I worked on. Stupid me, I though I was leaving the page this way.
fields.summary: Repository page: 'Leave repository' option in ... button. Please reconsider the option text.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Garbage file is intermittently counted in the repository size.

When pushing to the remote repository a GC is triggered afterwards which generates a garbage file. This garbage file is cleared on the next subsequent GC.
Between those two GC's the size of the repository is displayed incorrectly within Bitbucket UI as the garbage file size is intermittently counted towards the repository total size.


h3. Steps to Reproduce
 * Push files to the remote

h3. Expected Results
* Local repository size match the repository size of the remote.

h3. Actual Results
* Repository size of the remote is larger than what is seen locally.

h3. Workaround

Workaround is to request support to run a GC or wait until the next iteration of the GC is run after a push.
If the repository size + the garbage file size is over 2GB, which is our hard limit for repository size, the repository will be set in read only state and users will not be able to push any further and will necessarily require support assistance to clear their repository size.
fields.summary: Garbage file intermittently counted in the repository size

fields.description:
Currently, Bitbucket supports text description to be added and Images cannot be added. If we attempt to embed an URL with the image the image doesn't populate rather, the URL does.

The suggestion here is to allow users to add images via the API 2.0 for pull request description.

*Workaround:*
You would currently do this via the Pull request UI under the description field using the editor.
fields.summary: Adding Images via API

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When I try to create a single PR, 2 identical PRs get created instead.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Be me (Trello android developer)
 # Push code to our git repo
 # copy the link to create a PR from the command line
 # Open the link, fill in details, create the PR
 # TWO DUPLICATE PRs are created.

h3. Expected Results

1 PR is created.
h3. Actual Results

2 duplicate PRs are created. (this has happened twice for me today, and I've only tried to create 2 PRs) 
h3. Workaround

Delete one of the PRs.
fields.summary: Creating a PR on bitbucket cloud creates 2 identical PRs

fields.description:
As per the title, this feature request is to add a section or tab to list all of the Jira issues linked to commits in a pull request or a branch merge.

This would allow users to test against each issue if it's been resolved or if there's any further testing that needs to be done on the issues associated with the commits in the merge.

eg. 

!BCLOUD-19791.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: List all associated Jira issues associated with a merge

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary The Bitbucket API endpoint /2.0/repositories/\{workspace}/\{repo_slug}/issues/import is giving an error. h3. Steps to Reproduce # Try to import the issues to a repo using the API curl call, you will get the error as shown below {code:java} curl --user dheeraj_bhat:app_password -X POST -F archive=@/Users/documents/test.zip https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories///issues/import We ran into a minor glitch — Bitbucket

Something went wrong

While we check things on our end, refresh the page and contact support if the problem persists.

When contacting support, provide them with this code:

2d78f2ac3a814c51ad9bfcc44e714376

Our status page may also provide additional details.

{code}   h3. Expected Results The API should successfully import the issues to the repository. h3. Actual Results Getting error as mentioned above. h3. Workaround Import from the Bitbucket UI is working fine. Use UI to import. [Import issue data - documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/export-or-import-issue-data-330797432.html]
fields.summary: The Bitbucket API endpoint /2.0/repositories/{workspace}/{repo_slug}/issues/import is not working

fields.description:
Usres seek a more detailed folder view on the UI apart from the already existing projects. The limitation being:
1. Limited folders within projects
2. Want a better file structure view
3. Have folders and inside these folders have repositories 
4. Limited management capabilities for Project to be managed

*Workaround:*
Users may consider using git submodules
Link: https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Git-Tools-Submodules
fields.summary: Better Folder Structure for Bitbucket Cloud

fields.description:
At this time, Slack notifications for Pull request doesn't trigger for filters created for the source branch. And, only the destination branch involved in the Pull requests are being considered for the existing notification parameters (e.g. Pull request created, Pull request merged, etc)

It would be great to have notification parameters specifically for the source branch within Pull Requests.
fields.summary: To add Slack notifications for Pull Requests with specific source Branch

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Unable to edit SSH key label in repositories access key, it will give an error "For security reasons, you can't modify the contents of an access key. To update, delete and re-add the key."

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to repositories settings
 # Acess key > click edit any of the key
 # Change the key label and click save

h3. Expected Results
According to our documentation [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/use-access-keys-294486051.html] we allowed the user to edit the label but not the key for security purpose.
h3. Actual Results
User unable to edit the label key which returns a misleading error message.

h3. Workaround
No workaround at this moment
fields.summary: Unable to edit SSH key label in repositories access key

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce:*
 # Go to [https://bitbucket.org/dashboard/repositories]
 # Search for 'go-shared'

*Expected result:*

Search should return something relevant i.e. repositories that contain in their name 'go-shared' term, ideally matches should be highlighted in some way.

 

*Actual result:*

I see one matching repo (its name contains provided search term) and number of absolutely irrelevant repositories (their names and descriptions do NOT contain search term)

!image-2020-01-09-10-07-56-980.png!
fields.summary: Repository search returns repos that do not match search request
Making an API call to projects returns incorrect Repositories URI

fields.description:
We would like Bitbucket to, by default, display the Public Name of the committer on Public repositories instead of the Full name.

Currently, if our account has an Organization we are able to set up the Full Name visibility to "Only the member of the organization" and, after that done, Bitbucket will show the Public Name to all users that are not a member of the organization but:
# The same is not applied to non-members of organization accounts 
# If we have users of other organizations working on the same private repository, they will also not be able to see our Full Name.
fields.summary: Public Name displayed in Public Repositories

fields.description: Some customer requires to have a complete documentation on how to setup Java and Google Cloud App Engine deployment step by step.
fields.summary: Complete guide documentation for a Java and Google App Engine deployment

fields.description: You're still running git 2.10.5 from 2017. Please consider updating to 2.11.1 so your servers support the `deepen-since` capability (`git fetch --shallow-since` on the CLI). Thanks.
fields.summary: Update Git version to 2.11.1

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Here is the swagger file: [https://api.bitbucket.org/swagger.json]

There are a number of pages that are queryable with the `q` parameter but they aren't documented specifically for each resource that supports it.
h3. Expected Results

I expect that the documentation for this resource: [https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/repositories/%7Bworkspace%7D] would explicitly list `q` as a querystring variable. I expect it would be both in the documentation and in the swagger file.
h3. Actual Results

The `q` param is not listed. This makes it hard for some auto-generated clients to be able to pass this in as a variable.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

Go here: [https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/repositories/%7Bworkspace%7D] and see that `q` isn't listed as a query param.
h3. Workaround

Unsure.
fields.summary: Bitbucket OpenAPI spec doesn't always specify when a list is queryable.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When an account has the New PR view enabled and a comment drafted on a PR (Not saved yet) and the user resizes the window to something smaller than the text area (When it becomes mobile view) the page refreshes and the comment is cleared.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Enable 'New pull request experience' on the account
 # Navigate to a Pull Request
 # Draft a comment (Don't save)
 # Resize the browser window so it triggers mobile view 
 # The drafted comment is cleared

h3. Expected Results

The drafted comment should remain as drafted and should not clear
h3. Actual Results

The page refreshes and drafted comment is cleared
h3. Workaround
 * Disable the 'New pull request experience' in Bitbucket labs to use old pull request view
 * Avoid resizing the browser window before saving the comment.
fields.summary: Resizing the browser window on the new pull request view clears drafted comments

fields.description:
New Pull Request UI is great, but having "Files" on the right and "Content" on the left confuses mind during working with it. That's because all code editors have UI where you see "Files" on the left and "Content" on the right. When I review pull request, it's not just work in Bitbucket, but continues switching from Bitbucket to my local code editor. When I see something wrong in submitted pr and if it's something minor, I fix it immediately on my local copy of pull request branch and push. If there are multiple files in pull request, this "switching" happens continuously and it's a little bit hard to work in two so different UIs at one moment.

So, my suggestion is either to move "Files" to the left permanently or give user possibility to do it in some way.

Compare these two images, the first one is current UI screenshot and the second - the one, where I moved "Files" to the left using my Image Editor.

   !image-2020-01-06-15-47-02-582.png!

!image-2020-01-06-15-47-19-014.png!
fields.summary: Make it possible to move "Files" section to the left in New Pull Request UI
Allow use of SSO password on HTTPS local operations

fields.description: It would be great to have an API endpoint to identify whether LFS is enabled on the repository or not. OR, to have a new property added to '/2.0/repositories/\{workspace}/\{repo_slug}' endpoint with details related to LFS status on the repository.
fields.summary: API endpoint to identify if LFS is enabled on repository

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Offline flag is misaligned

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Step 1
Lose connection to Bitbucket somehow. Disable internet connection?
 # Step 2
Wait for red "You are currently offline" flag to show up

h3. Expected Results
Flag is correctly aligned in the bottom left corner of the screen

h3. Actual Results
Bottom half of flag is cut off by the bottom of the screen. See attachment.

The below exception is thrown in the xxxxxxx.log file:
{noformat}
...
{noformat}

h3. Workaround
 Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior.
fields.summary: "You are offline" flag is misaligned

fields.description:
It would be good to have the ability to load a diff only to the file you want, opposite to the current behavior where the entire diff still needs to load or having to blacklist files on the repository settings.

When working with large projects, there may be multiple changes that are irrelevant to the code that needs to get reviewed. Being able to selective load diffs on the pull request by, for example, clicking on the file on the right-hand side list of files would improve the page load time for the final user.
fields.summary: Add selective diff load for pull requests

fields.description:
As per the title, this feature request is to change the code view scroll from being inside a panel and to make it scroll the whole page instead.

This would help the code preview in cases where the display is not big enough, and the heading (file name, Source/diff/history links, etc) takes a big chunk of the screen. This feature request aims to mitigate that, by having the code preview page scroll the whole page instead.

See the image attached.
fields.summary: Change Bitbucket code view to scroll the entire page instead of a panel

fields.description:
Currently, Bitbucket allows users to disable 2SV with just clicking the 'Disable two-step verification'.

In order to provide best-in-class security, having a 2SV token verification in place before disabling 2SV on Bitbucket would be a good feature.
fields.summary: 2SV token verification to be required before disabling 2SV on Bitbucket

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When adding code to an inline comment and the code language is selected and saved the code language pop-up remains on the screen. 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Navigate to Pull Request 
 # Add an inline comment by clicking '+' next tot he line number
 # Selected '<>' for code block
 # Select the code language
 # Add the comment
 # Save

h3. Expected Results

The language selector clears as soon as the comment is saved
h3. Actual Results

The language selector remains and is not cleared
h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Selecting a code language when adding code as an inline comment, the code language pop-up remains

fields.description:
Hi there, could you please add a button on the web UI that can force a prune/GC-cycle on repositories so that we can minimize their size?

It feels extremely silly to have to file a support issue every time – as is currently needed as per your support article ([https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/reduce-repository-size-321848262.html])
fields.summary: Add ability to manually invoke a prune/GC clean-up from the Web UI

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Bitbucket page is not rendered when using Chrome mobile 79.0.3945.93 on Pixel 3 XL on Android 10.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # On Pixel 3 XL, open Chrome mobile 79.0.3945.93 and access [https://bitbucket.org/]
 # login to your account

h3. Expected Results
* Bitbucket UI is rendered using mobile UI.

h3. Actual Results
* Bitbucket mobile UI is not rendered
**  !Screenshot_20191227-113313.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround
Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Mobile UI is not properly rendered when accessing Bitbucket from Chrome mobile 79.0.3945.93 on Pixel 3 XL on Android 10.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When a user who is not an administrator of any Bitbucket team tries to create a project, this action fails. This is expected behavior, as you need to have team administrator permissions in order to create a project.

However, there is no message shown to the user, to inform them the reason why it is not possible for them to create a project.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

Log in to a Bitbucket account that does not have Admin access to any Bitbucket team
 # Go to [https://bitbucket.org/dashboard/projects]
 # Select the link "Create project" from the top right corner

OR
 # From the left sidebar navigation, select +
 # Then select Create > Project

h3. Expected Results

See a dialog with the following info:
 - informing the user that they need to have admin access to a team, before creating a project
 - asking the user to create a Bitbucket team, or reach out to their team admin, if they are already a member of a team.

h3. Actual Results

Following the steps above, the page [https://bitbucket.org/account/projects/create] does NOT load for the user.
 So, nothing happens and the user doesn't see any message with info on why the "Create project" page does not open.

 [^CreateProject_Bug.mov] 

h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: "Create project" fails for users without team admin access, without a dialog informing the user of the reason why

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Bitbucket UI doesn't respect landing page settings on repository home page.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
1. Change landing page for your repository to be the `commits`page.
2. Go to your repository home page.
3 Click the repository's name at top of the side menu.

h3. Expected Results
The user is redirected to the 'commits' page.

h3. Actual Results
The user is always redirected to the `source` view instead of the commits page.

h3. Workaround
There is no workaround to this behavior at the current moment.
fields.summary: Bitbucket UI doesn't respect landing page settings on repository home page

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When deleting merged branches, the branches view switches to the 'All branches' view even though the 'Merged branches' drop-down option is selected. 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Navigate to a repo with many merged branches
 # Navigates to the "Branches" page.
 # Select the "Merged branches" from the drop-down (by default it is set to "All branches")
 # Use the dots menu to the right of each branch. 
 # Click the dots > Delete > OK.
 # Delete one or a few branches from the list
 # After deleting the branch(s) list branches changes to display ALL branches, the drop-down selection remains as 'Merged branches'

h3. Expected Results

The list of branches should NOT change and remain to display the merged branches. If a user is not careful, they can unintentionally delete an active branch.
Actual Results
h3. Actual Results

The list of branches changes displaying all active branches.
h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available.
fields.summary: Deleting a merged branch changes the branches view to all active branches

fields.description:
Hi,
Currently, we don't have a one-one mapping or one to many mapping with the user groups and the projects in bitbuckets.
let's say we have projects A, B,C, D, and E.
Also, we have 4 user groups namely W, X, Y,Z.
I want users to
 * group X to access only source code repositories under A and B Projects.
 * group Y to access only source code repositories under B, C and D Projects

but currently, there is no feature to map user group to a project instead we explicitly select all the repositories or individual repositories to provide access the group members. which is kind of a pain to manage when you have 120 repos.
fields.summary: Mapping User Groups to Projects in Bitbucket

fields.description:
Hi,
Currently, we don't have a one-one mapping or one to many mapping with the user groups and the projects in bitbuckets.
let's say we have projects A, B,C, D, and E.
Also, we have 4 user groups namely W, X, Y,Z.
I want users to
 * group X to access only source code repositories under A and B Projects.
 * group Y to access only source code repositories under B, C and D Projects

but currently, there is no feature to map user group to a project instead we explicitly select all the repositories or individual repositories to access the group. which is kind of a pain to manage when you have 120 repos.
fields.summary: Mapping User Groups to Projects in Bitbucket

fields.description: One or more users are asking about a feature of enabling notifications (any kind of notifications, would be like a panel where you set up which notifications you want to receive in each address) for the e-mail aliases of the Bitbucket Accounts.
fields.summary: Set up e-mail notifications for Aliases.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary - 
Bitbucket Cloud doesn't provide functionality to restore deleted group
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Delete a group from Bitbucket account
 # The group is deleted from the account
 # There is no option to restore the deleted group

h3. Expected Results 
Bitbucket Cloud should provide option to restore deleted group
h3. Actual Results 

Bitbucket Cloud doesn't provide option to restore deleted group
h3. Workaround
 # Recreate the group with same name
 # Add the users one one by in the group which were part of the deleted group
fields.summary: No feature to restore deleted group

fields.description:
h3. Summary
In the https://bitbucket.org/<username>/<repository>/pull-requests page, selecting a branch from the branch select will perform a search using the branch name rather than returning results only for that specific branch. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a new branch that has the name "master" in it. In my example, I've created "master-two-three"
# Make a commit with a different branch.
# Create a new pull request with the newly created branch as the target branch. 
# Go to https://bitbucket.org/<username>/<repository>/pull-requests
# Select the target branch as "master".

h3. Expected Results
The page only shows pull requests that belongs to the "master" branch,

h3. Actual Results
The page returns pull requests that belongs to branches which has the name "master" in them. 
 
h3.Workaround
There is no workaround as for now. 

 !image-2019-12-24-22-40-27-137.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: The branch select on the Pull request page performs a search using the branch name rather than returning results only for that specific branch.

fields.description:
Currently, when you save files as cache in Pipelines, the timestamp of the files saved is based on the current Pipelines build the cache directory is downloaded and extracted.

*Example Scenario*:
 When SBT compares a local file to a remote as the local file is always newer. This means that caches may break builds due to outdated libraries in a given snapshot.
 [Caching dependencies - Atlassian Documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/caching-dependencies-895552876.html]

*Feature Request*:
 It would be useful to preserve the timestamp when the Cache was created not when it was extracted in a current build.
fields.summary: Preserve Timestamp in Pipelines Cache

fields.description:
It would be a useful feature if the pull requests would still be approved when we do a sync with the destination branch to an unrelated file.

Steps to reproduce:

1) Create a new branch and make some changes to a single file. Commit and push.
2) Create pull request to merge to the `default' branch.
3) Approve PR.
4) Make some changes to an unrelated file on the `default` branch. Commit and push.
5) Select `Sync now` on the PR to bring the new branch up to date with the `default` branch.
6) PR state changes to `Unapproved` - which is actually the expected behaviour as the source branch has changed.
fields.summary: Pull requests unapproved when sync with destination branch to an unrelated file

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

'*Edit YAML Configuration*' button throws '_{color:#ff8b00}The link has no power{color}_' error on the repository deployment tab when the main branch is set with a prefix. Example: 'release/master'

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Change the main branch from repository details to something with prefix e.g 'release/master'
 # Go to deployment tab and click: '_Edit YAML Configuration_'

h3. Expected Results

The option '*Edit YAML Configuration*' at Repository Deployments tab should redirect to 'bitbucket-pipelines.yml' preset at Source tab

h3. Actual Results

Error out with the following error:
{noformat}
The link has no power
{noformat}

!image001 (1).png|width=284,height=154!

h3. Workaround
 * Opening 'bitbucket-pipelines.yml' directly from the Source tab.
fields.summary: Edit YAML Configuration option at Repository Deployments tab throws error with the main branch having a prefix

fields.description:
We'd like to be able to connect to both JIRA Cloud and BitBucket Cloud using a single token (per user of course).
At the moment it's impossible to use the JIRA token to login to BitBucket (to send REST API requests for example).
That forces us to use the JIRA token for JIRA API requests and the BitBucket login credentials (user, pw) for BitBucket REST API requests.



Trying to use the JIRA credentials to make REST API requests to BitBucket failed with code 401.

I'd like to combine the two somehow and use just 1 set of credentials in my Python script to make rest API requests to both JIRA and BitBucket  for example.

both JIRA and BitBucket are cloud versions.
fields.summary: Using a single API token for both JIRA and BitBucket Cloud

fields.description: Currently, it's hard for admin to manage the user IP whitelist especially if the user is using static IP. An ability for the user to manually make a remark when they hit the error to inform the admin about their new IP.
fields.summary: User can make a remarks for IP whitelisting

fields.description: When a PR is declined it would help others to understand why when that reason is clearly shown in the PR overview page instead of having to click through to the "Activity" page where it easliy missed.
fields.summary: Show decline reason in PR overview page

fields.description: Bash is not offered as a language in the project setting. Curiously, zsh is. Why not Bash?
fields.summary: Bash is not offered as a language in the project setting

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Diff page shows line numbers different from the file content

Bitbucket compare functionality intermittently shows different line numbers compared to the line numbers from the file (on that commit).


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Click on the + icon on the left panel > click on _Compare branches or tags_
# Select two sources to compare
# Click on the _diff_ tab

h3. Expected Results
The diff shows changes from each file preserving its original line number

h3. Actual Results
The diff shows changes from each file, displaying the wrong line number

h3. Workaround
Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Bitbucket's compare shows different line numbers when comparing files

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

File renaming causes the file in the PR using the New pull request experience to count as a deletion of older file and creation of new file. 
 If the number of lines in the file is more than 2000 lines, UI is unable to render the file and generates an error message: 
 "Diff too large
 The diff for this file is too large to render."
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a file with more than 2000 lines.
 # Rename the file.
 # Create a Pull request with this commit

h3. Expected Results

The Pull request should show "File renamed but contents unchanged." message for renamed files.
h3. Actual Results

Pull request UI is unable to render the file and generates an error message: 
 "Diff too large
 The diff for this file is too large to render."
h3. Workaround
 # Ignore the error and files which have been renamed in Pull request
 # Disable New pull request experience and enable Old pull request experience Lab Feature.
fields.summary: File renaming causes the file in the PR using the New pull request experience to count as a new file

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Currently, it is not possible to log into Bitbucket using the U2F authentication method while using IOS as the following message states:

 !image-2019-12-20-10-58-31-230.png|thumbnail! 

(i) Behavior confirmed to both Safari and Chrome

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to bitbucket.org
 # Try to log in using the U2F option (previously set up).

h3. Expected Results

Be allowed to use the U2F to authenticate.

h3. Actual Results

Error message:
 !image-2019-12-20-10-58-31-230.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround

Use the verification code form the authentication App (2FA) instead of the U2F.
fields.summary: Unable to log into Bitbucket with U2F while in mobile device.

fields.description:
The current review option in a PR allows us to add a set of default reviewers for a repo.

But what would be ideal is to enable certain default reviewers to a subset such as a selected folder or certain files.

For instance,

*.sh there should be reviewer1 and reviewer2 added
* ** database * implies that all database folder or files should have reviewerA and reviewerB added
fields.summary: Specify Mandatory reviewers for folders/files within a repo
